jurisdiction.name: New Jersey
jurisdiction.transparency_law: New Jersey Open Public Records Act (OPRA)

validation_metadata.verification_method: Direct review of N.J.S.A. 47:1A-1 et seq. including 2024 amendments

rights_of_access.description: Legislature declares government records shall be readily accessible for inspection, copying, or examination by citizens, with limitations construed in favor of public's right of access.
rights_of_access.conditions: Records must be readily accessible; limitations construed favoring access; applies to citizens of New Jersey
rights_of_access.applies_to: All government records in New Jersey
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: 'Readily accessible' requires affirmative agency efforts; construction favoring access resolves ambiguities for requesters; citizenship requirement may limit enforcement
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert: 'N.J.S.A. 47:1A-1 declares records shall be readily accessible with limitations construed favoring public access. Please provide [records] under this presumption.'

rights_of_access.description: Standard requests must receive response within 7 business days. Commercial use requests extended to 14 business days under 2024 amendments.
rights_of_access.conditions: 7 business days for standard requests; 14 business days for commercial use (effective Sept 2024); must provide written response
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: 2024 amendments differentiated commercial vs non-commercial timelines; commercial users face longer wait
rights_of_access.request_tips: Cite timeline: 'N.J.S.A. 47:1A-5 requires response within 7 business days for standard requests (14 for commercial). This is a [standard/commercial] request. Please respond by [date].'

rights_of_access.description: First 10 pages of copies provided at no charge. Additional pages charged at actual cost of duplication.
rights_of_access.conditions: First 10 pages always free; subsequent pages at actual duplication cost; electronic records at actual cost only
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Ensures small requests cost nothing; actual cost standard prevents inflated fees
rights_of_access.request_tips: Cite free pages: 'N.J.S.A. 47:1A-5 provides first 10 pages free. Please provide at no cost, charging only actual duplication costs for additional pages.'

rights_of_access.description: Custodian shall disclose portions of a record which are not exempt under OPRA.
rights_of_access.conditions: Mandatory segregation; must disclose non-exempt portions; cannot withhold entire document when portions are public
rights_of_access.applies_to: Partially exempt records in New Jersey
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Prevents overbroad withholding; agencies must perform redaction analysis and produce public portions
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert segregability: 'N.J.S.A. 47:1A-5(c) requires you to disclose non-exempt portions. Please produce all non-exempt information with only specific exempt portions redacted.'

rights_of_access.description: Person denied access may file complaint with Government Records Council (GRC). GRC provides mediation services and formal investigation with prescribed decision timeframes.
rights_of_access.conditions: File complaint with GRC; mediation available; formal investigation if mediation fails; appealable to Appellate Division
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Specialized oversight body; mediation encourages informal resolution; formal process available if needed
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert GRC appeal: 'I may file a complaint with the Government Records Council under N.J.S.A. 47:1A-6. Please reconsider to avoid GRC mediation and investigation.'

rights_of_access.description: Under 2024 amendments, prevailing requester entitled to attorney fees only if agency unreasonably denied access, acted in bad faith, or knowingly/willfully violated OPRA. Exception: If agency provides records within 7 days of being served, fees only if agency knew or should have known denial violated OPRA.
rights_of_access.conditions: Requires unreasonable denial, bad faith, or knowing violation; 7-day cure provision limits fees; more restrictive than pre-2024 law
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: 2024 amendments significantly raised bar for attorney fees; encourages quick curing of denials within 7 days; protects agencies making good faith errors
rights_of_access.request_tips: Note 2024 standard: 'Under 2024 OPRA amendments, I may recover attorney fees if your denial is unreasonable, in bad faith, or knowing/willful violation. Please reconsider promptly to avoid potential fee liability.'
